context_text:
I was born in Genoa in 2001, where I lived for about five more years. After that, my family—my father, mother, and younger brother—moved to Sardinia. This was because my father is originally from Sardinia, and my parents always believed that our childhood and upbringing would be better in a small Sardinian village than in a big city like Genoa.
I learned to cook out of pure desire (not that I'm a great chef), but my mother and father have always cooked, and for this reason, and because of every child's curiosity about the world of adults, I tried my hand at cooking at a very young age. For example, when I was 12 or 13, my parents knew that if they were away for half a day, I would be able to cook lunch for myself and my younger brother. I still remember that the first dish I cooked was a simple pasta dish with sauce, helped by my mother, of course, and for this reason it's still one of my favorite dishes. Furthermore, my grandmother (like all grandmothers) always cooked a lot, and let's just say that food has always been a part of my life. Even today, when I go out with friends or my girlfriend, my favorite and most satisfying moment is definitely when we sit down to eat, whether at home or at a pizzeria or restaurant. When it comes to food traditions, my parents have always been strict, in the good sense of the word. In fact, at home we have a wide-ranging diet that includes practically every type of food, and we rarely consume overly processed or overly industrial foods. 
I've had the opportunity to travel quite a bit in recent years, especially in Europe, and especially in Portugal and Spain. The cuisines I've tasted aren't that different from our own in terms of ingredients, but I was pleasantly surprised by some typical dishes, like paella and Francesinha. For now, I feel I must mention two other cuisines that I particularly love: Asian and Indian, which I appreciate for their flavours and especially for the spices used. I also feel compelled to mention some of my all-time favorite dishes, including lasagna, pizza, pasta with turnip tops, and pumpkin and sausage risotto. I don't have any allergies, and the sport I practice doesn't require any specific diet, so these are my dietary preferences, and I hope I've explained them clearly enough.

I'm a student away from home, I'm from Nuxis, but I've lived from 3 years in Cagliari.
I started cooking during my first year away from home. Initially, my mother would prepare some of the more complex dishes for me, and I'd just reheat them. But as time went by, I began to get used to it and experiment with simple recipes. I also discovered that I enjoy cooking, but above all, eating delicious yet healthy foods. Since living away from my family, I've learned to eat properly, with the right macronutrients my body needs. My favorite foods are pizza and seafood fregola. During my trip to Edinburgh, I discovered Japanese cuisine. I ate ramen and gyoza for the first time, and I loved it right away. In fact, I sometimes go to restaurants here in Cagliari to eat them. I've also tried other cuisines, like Malaysian and Indian, but I didn't particularly like Indian cuisine; it's too spicy for my taste. My cooking style now revolves around preparing quick meals that can be eaten cold the next day for lunch at university during the week. On weekends, when I have more free time and eat lunch at home, I have more time and the opportunity to create more sophisticated dishes. I'd like to take up a sport, because I spend all day sitting at the computer, but right now I can't fit it into my routine due to my busy schedule. As soon as I have some free time, I'd like to go running again, just to unwind and have a more balanced diet to lose weight. My problem is sweets; I can't do without them.

Hi, I'm a guy from Cagliari who likes cooking and food. My cooking skills, which are quite basic, were mainly learned by getting inspired by dishes I saw in my social circle (family, friends, etc.) or through social networks (mainly TikTok, to a lesser extent YouTube, and even less on Instagram), where based on my tastes I tried to recreate them in my own way. My preference between sweet and savory falls on the latter because after going through a period of gym and serious diet that led me to almost never eat sweets, sweet food tends to make me nauseous very quickly and to be honest I don't even feel the need to eat particularly sweet foods. The gym, although not in an exaggerated way, has shaped my current view of food, because it helped me discover healthy but also tasty foods, it helped me discard others that were too harmful, so unconsciously and automatically if I have the possibility and, above all, the desire, I tend to prefer the healthier foods discovered with that lifestyle. As banal as it may be, my favorite cuisine is Italian because it manages to find the right balance between taste, variety, heaviness on the stomach, and healthiness. While among the various cuisines I've tried, Spanish, Hungarian, French, German, and Chinese, my favorite is the last one, which is the only one that made me try totally new and particularly strong flavors but without being stomach-churning and difficult to digest. As for various intolerances, I have problems mainly related to histamine which doesn't cause me serious consequences but if eaten in quantity creates skin rashes and swelling, so I try to avoid bingeing on foods that have high values of this substance.

I live in Sardinia and have never lived abroad for long periods (maximum 2 weeks). I learned to cook when I was about 6 years old, first helping my parents and then on my own so that I could make my own lunch, since both my parents worked outside the home. I studied nutrition in high school, so I have some knowledge in this area. At 17, I chose bodybuilding as my sport, which led me to pay more attention to the amount of calories and the quality of the food I eat, but at the expense of variety in my diet, which is particularly monotonous in order to fit within the macronutrients. Since starting university, I have less time to train, but my cooking style remains purely functional, simple and clean meals like lean meat and carbohydrates, like pasta or potatoes, or rice. I have traveled a lot, both in Italy and abroad, and I always try to taste the typical dishes of the places I visit, even if I don't really like them. I hate strong flavors, spices, and foods that are too fatty or sugary. I don't particularly enjoy eating, so I don't often go to restaurants or places specifically for that purpose, and when I do, it's usually more for the company than for the food. The only times I have experienced happiness while eating were at Heinz Beck's restaurant and at Ristorante Guinceri, both times eating meat.

I am from India, where food and flavor are an important part of everyone’s life. I grew up with simple, home-cooked meals, which shaped my preference for comforting dishes that are not too heavy. After moving abroad for my studies, my relationship with food changed as I adapted to new environments, and lifestyles. Living in countries like Italy exposed me to different cuisines and ingredients, and I enjoy exploring new foods while still preferring flavors that feel familiar and balanced. Through my travels, I’ve learned to enjoy experimenting with new flavors, but I still tend to prefer dishes that are healthy, as I try to maintain a healthy diet.

I usually cook simple meals for myself that are easy to prepare. I enjoy foods that are not overly spicy, and balanced. I also appreciate international cuisines, especially those with familiar ingredients. Eating out or trying new foods has become a way for me to explore different cultures, but I always return to the comfort of the meals I grew up with.

I was born and raised in Cagliari as an only child, and most of my early exposure to food came from daily home cooking. I learned to cook by watching my mother, gradually picking up basic techniques rather than following formal recipes. Over time, this led me to prefer simple, practical dishes based on pasta, rice, and legumes. I tend not to prepare elaborate meat dishes, and I almost never cook fish myself, although fish has always been a regular part of my diet when I eat at my parents’ home.

Travel has contributed to broadening my understanding of different cuisines. I always try local dishes when visiting new places, even though I rarely attempt to replicate them once I return home. They usually remain linked to the context of the trip rather than becoming part of my everyday cooking routine.

After the age of twenty-five, my lifestyle became more sedentary, and moving out of my parents’ home introduced further changes. The transition brought more flexibility but also less consistency, occasionally leading to less structured eating habits. Despite this, I cook on a daily basis and generally follow a Mediterranean pattern, alternating pasta, rice, and legumes, and incorporating meat or occasionally fish (mainly when I eat with my parents) several times a week.

I enjoy watching cooking programs like MasterChef and various food vlogs, but these rarely influence what I choose to cook. For the same reason, I don’t associate myself with a specific restaurant or signature dish. Overall, my food choices are shaped mainly by routine, practicality, and the culinary habits I developed growing up.

I come from Sicily, and there are four of us at home: my mom, my dad, my brother, and me. I’ve always lived in a loving and peaceful family. My mom has always loved cooking, so having always seen her in the kitchen, I learned from her. One of our traditions is definitely eating pasta at least once a day, usually at lunch. Now that I live on my own, I eat a bit healthier, because back home my mother never measured anything, whereas now I try to ‘limit myself’. I’ve also discovered new ways of cooking and started using spices and experimenting more by trying new foods. I eat vegetables with every meal—usually with pasta at lunch and with a main dish at dinner, whether it’s meat, fish, or eggs. I’m lactose intolerant, so I don’t eat any kind of dairy product, also because, to be honest, I don’t even like them. I enjoy eating typical Sicilian dishes, especially when I go back home, but sometimes I cook them myself too, because I really enjoy cooking, especially for others.

Born and raised in Turin. I learned to cook by following my parents’ instructions, starting with desserts because they were easier to prepare and learn. I gathered ingredients and dishes thanks to trips I took to various countries. Joining the gym didn’t particularly change my way of eating; I’ve always been mindful of what I chose to eat. I currently cook the three main meals every day, trying to vary my food sources while maintaining a standard in terms of proportions. I’m someone who has no allergies or intolerances but still follows a certain dietary regimen for sports performance, loosening up a bit during the weekend. Being an active and athletic person makes my diet very important and central to my lifestyle, though it doesn’t create any social or mental issues for me. I am determined to achieve the goals I set for myself.
Besides Italian cuisine, the cuisines that have left a strong impression on me are Greek cuisine, because it’s light and flavorful, as well as the traditional cuisines of the Balkan countries.

I am a 29-year-old Italian guy, originally from Piedmont, a region in northern Italy. I have lived mainly in Italy, but in the past I spent about a year in London, England. My family has Piedmontese origins, but also southern Italian origins on my great-grandmother's side.

I learned to cook by watching my mother when I was little, as she is an excellent cook who learned both from her life in Piedmont and from her grandmother, who came from southern Italy. 
For me, traditional food is Piedmontese food, as I have been eating it since I was a child. This cuisine uses many ingredients (from vegetables to meat) and generally has strong flavors (one of the typical dishes has only anchovies, garlic, and oil as ingredients). Other typical dishes are polenta with stew, meat (both raw and cooked in different ways, such as boiled), and fresh stuffed pasta such as agnolotti.
At home with my parents, I always ate classic Italian dishes (including lots of vegetables and meat) or traditional Piedmontese dishes, but my mother often cooked typical dishes from southern Italy or made fresh pasta. 

Despite my Italian origins, I have tried many different cuisines: one of my favorites is Moroccan. During my time in London, I hated English food, so I continued to eat and prepare Italian dishes.
Since I've been living alone, I've started eating less meat and more vegetables, mainly because of the ever-increasing cost of meat. 
Now I generally eat and cook classic Italian dishes. My diet is fairly standard: lots of pasta, all kinds of vegetables, cheese, and meat (both chicken and beef). 
Given my origins, I continue to appreciate very strong flavors, such as very mature cheeses.
I often cook classic dishes that are quick to prepare, including salads with lettuce, tomatoes, and any vegetables, pasta with sauce or pesto, or even meals such as piadina with cold cuts (such as prosciutto).

I don't eat desserts, as I don't particularly like them, but I love coffee.
I have no allergies or intolerances, and I don't follow any particular diet or restrictions. 
In general, I am a person who eats a lot, and I occasionally enjoy eating street food.

I was born in Piedmont and have always lived in the town of Savigliano. I live with my parents, so my mother primarily cooks. I learned my cooking skills from her, and I sometimes cook when I'm home alone or when my brother is present. I haven't had any major events that have impacted my eating habits; in recent years, after COVID, I've simply been trying to maintain a balanced diet, also with the help of my brother, who is taking nutrition courses. My favorite cuisine is Italian, and my favorite foods are pizza and pasta. I've tried some European and non-European cuisines (such as Egyptian), but these experiences have confirmed that Italian cuisine is my favorite. During meals at local restaurants, I learned to appreciate some foods I hadn't eaten before (especially vegetables like eggplant and artichokes). YouTube videos featuring restaurant reviews have definitely helped me choose restaurants more carefully when I'm out. Now, with my new job, I have to prepare lunch and plan what to eat for the whole week since I can't get home. This is a challenge for me, trying to maintain a balanced diet without resorting to the classic foods everyone loves.
I'm used to eating pasta almost every day, trying to balance my other meals by alternating fish and meat, usually accompanied by vegetables.
I've always loved sweets, but in recent years I've been trying to avoid always ending my meal with this type of food. Another habit I have is always having coffee after lunch.

Food has always been deeply woven into my personal and cultural identity. Growing up in Italy, I learned early on that food is far more than nourishment—it’s a language of care, tradition, and creativity. My earliest memories involve long family meals where recipes were passed down through conversation rather than written instructions. Those moments taught me to value the sensory aspects of cooking—the smell of fresh herbs, the texture of handmade pasta, the slow transformation of ingredients into something comforting and communal.

Over the years, my relationship with food has evolved from following tradition to exploring it. I enjoy experimenting with both regional dishes and new flavors, often combining elements of Friulian cuisine with influences from my travels and research stays abroad. Cooking has become a meditative process and a way of balancing my analytical work in technology with something tactile and expressive.

Food also connects strongly to my interest in sustainability and mindful living. I try to cook seasonally, minimize waste, and understand where my ingredients come from. Developing a recipe or refining a dish feels similar to solving a creative problem—one guided by intuition, attention, and care. Ultimately, food for me represents continuity: between culture and innovation, between community and individuality, between memory and discovery.

I grew up in a family where there was always a lot of cooking, especially with my grandparents, and I was always included from a young age in family cooking.
I started cooking alone around middle school, when my brother and I came home and had to start cooking by ourselves.
In my first years of university I lived with my grandparents, my favorite dish was my grandmother's meat sauce lasagna.
In the first years when I moved to live alone, if I was with someone I would gladly cook, otherwise given the lack of desire I always ended up eating foods that were almost ready or with little preparation: flatbreads, pasta, potatoes, but I always ate a lot of vegetables and fruit.
In recent years I started following a vegetarian diet first, and then due to digestive problems I started removing dairy products until now following a vegan diet.
I have also always had a series of digestive problems, which in recent years have worsened; this is having an impact on what I eat as I try to always eat lightly seasoned or foods that don't trigger reactions in my intestine. During this period I realize I have developed some issues in this regard, as when I think about what to eat I always also think about what effect it might have on my digestion.

I come from Cagliari in Italy. My food preferences are mainly oriented towards savoury foods. I don't really like desserts because of the calories and the impact of fats on digestion, which means the body has to work harder to digest them, leading to fatigue, etc. I really like pizza, but not Neapolitan pizza. I like it to be a little crispy with sauce and oregano. I like courgette flowers, peppers and vegetables in general, except broad beans because I'm allergic to them. I don't like chickpeas, beans or these vegetables. I eat yoghurt with kiwi and cereal, and I also really like pears, but not ripe ones, i.e. ones that are soft and watery. I like eggs cooked in a pan without the yolk breaking. I really like fried chicken. I also like making mixed salads, such as tomatoes, cucumbers, tuna and mozzarella, especially because they are quick to prepare. During the week, I need very quick and, above all, light dishes for lunch.

I am a PhD student and I was born in Turin, where I still live and study. My parents have been divorced since I was 3 years old and I grew up with my mother and my grandparents. My dad and my grandfather loved cooking, while my mother and my grandmother did not. I started cooking when I was 7 years old because I used to watch culinary TV programs and I wanted to experience it myself. The first dish I successfully cooked was pasta alla carbonara, using the original “Roman” recipe. I then continued searching for recipes for first courses, which are my favourite.
Currently I'm following an omnivore diet including a first dish (pasta or rice), a second (mainly fish and meat, sometimes legumes), and vegetables. I don't like dessert, for this reason it is rare that I cook something sweet.
I don't have allergies or pathology, thus my philosophy is basically "eat what you desire to eat," but in a Mediterranean diet style, because I'm used to it and I really enjoy it.
I also love Spanish cuisine, and tapas led me to appreciate a less traditional meal, not necessarily composed of a first course, second course, and side dish. Lately, I have also been experimenting with oriental cuisine (mainly noodles and dumplings). Related to this, I have introduced soy as an ingredient in preparations where I did not use it before.
The best culinary experiences come from my trips abroad, because I love trying new foods, but I cannot say that they have directly influenced my cooking. After all, I have never visited the East (China, Japan, or Korea), yet some of my favourite recipes originate from there.

My roots lie in the outskirts of the Piedmont region, where I grew up with an essential, rustic culinary culture deeply connected to the land. We ate simple foods like potatoes and zucchini, often seasoned just with a drizzle of oil. This upbringing formed my preference for genuine, no-frills flavors.

Currently, my life is split between my family home and Turin, where I live as an off-campus student. My approach to food during the week is almost "algorithmic": I seek maximum efficiency. For lunch, I rely on the university cafeteria, selecting large but balanced meals (high protein, carbs, and fiber) while avoiding greasy foods. Dinner is often an exercise in smart recycling: leftovers from lunch integrated with a quick pan-seared protein.

My background in Computer Science significantly impacts my habits. Often, the time spent coding in front of a screen causes me to forget or postpone meals. However, when I disconnect from my devices and finish my sports activities, I always look for healthy options. Despite the hectic schedule, I learned to cook by watching my mother and studying YouTube tutorials.

There is, however, one exception to my fast-paced routine: Ragù alla Bolognese. It is my signature dish and the only time when speed doesn't matter. I love letting it simmer for hours, waiting for that flavor transformation that only patience can provide. Seeing my family surprised by the taste of that dish is my greatest satisfaction—a return to slowness that balances my frenetic student life.

When I was younger, I was obese, primarily because of what I ate every day: industrial snacks, processed foods, sweets, chocolate, and very fatty ingredients. So, I decided to change, and I lost 60 kg in approximately one year. Since then, I have also started going to the gym and gaining muscle mass.

Now, I pay attention to every single ingredient I eat every day, calculating the calories and macronutrients of every meal, from breakfast to my pre-workout snack. Having done this for almost six years, my health has improved, as has my relationship with food. When I go to the supermarket, I read every single nutritional label to check if the ingredients are suitable for my meals.

I eat chicken breast every day; it is my primary protein source. Once or twice a week, I consume red meat, such as horse or beef. I also eat fish at least twice a week. Salmon is my favorite, but I also eat swordfish. I don't like tuna very much, but I sometimes eat it at Japanese restaurants.

As for carbohydrate sources, I usually eat rice, pasta, and rye bread, and sometimes rice cakes and crackers. Regarding fat sources, my favorites are extra virgin olive oil and Parmesan cheese, but I also enjoy extra dark chocolate (90%+). I also like cottage cheese and ricotta.

I have a cheat meal every two weeks, and I usually prefer to eat high-quality meat or go to a fish restaurant. I don't love pizza that much, but I eat it once every month or two.

I was born in Sardinia, more specifically in southern Sardinia. I have always lived between two places: Cagliari and my village, and I believe this has somehow influenced my daily eating habits due to the time involved in travelling between them. For a couple of months now, I have been seeing a nutritionist, who is teaching me how to eat healthily and adapt my diet to my weekly needs, including activities such as going to the gym and studying. Following the nutritionist's advice, I am currently on a Mediterranean-style diet. I can definitely say that my hobby of weight training also influences my eating habits, as I vary between different types of nutrition: body recomposition, mass gain or body definition. My favourite dish is pizza, but one dish I particularly remember enjoying is a seafood carbonara I tried in northern Sardinia: a cheese carbonara with tuna instead of the classic guanciale, bottarga and crumbled tarallo.

I have irritable bowel syndrome, so I have to follow a diet. I have crepes for breakfast every day; for lunch and dinner, I can eat carbohydrates such as rice, rice pasta, whole grain bread, and proteins such as fish, dairy products, or meat (both red and white). I always have to eat cooked vegetables. Occasionally, I can eat dark chocolate. As for drinks, I can only drink herbal teas and water. I can eat pizza once every two weeks, preferably gluten-free because it's better for me. I prefer to eat things that are quick to prepare. Often, when I cook lunch, I also make dinner to save time. It's difficult for me to eat out because there are many condiments I can't eat, and restaurants aren't very careful about that. My favourite food is pizza, If I could I would eat that every day. I also enjoy eating tomatoes.

I'm originally from Ogliastra but currently live in Cagliari as a non-resident student. I come from a large family, with parents who were always very present. At home my mom almost always cooked and the diet was quite varied: pasta, fish, meat, and fresh products. As a child I ate little and was quite thin, so food was never at the center of my interests.

I started cooking out of necessity when I moved to Cagliari. I wouldn't call myself a cooking enthusiast: I cook mainly for practicality, but I'm curious and open to different types of cuisine. In general, I don't really like stewed dishes, those with lots of vegetables mixed together, or meats that are too fatty. Among my favorite dishes are pizza, fish or ricotta ravioli, shrimp spaghetti, and, as a dessert, tiramisu. As fruit I gladly choose coconut, blackberries, and banana.

For about three years, since I started going to the gym, I've been paying more attention to my diet. I try to increase my protein intake and limit fats and sugars. I don't follow a strict diet, but I always try to balance my meals: when I can I choose sugar-free drinks and, even though I often eat in the cafeteria or sometimes order delivery or go to fast food, I still try not to overdo it. I have an important restriction: I have favism, so I must avoid fava beans. My current goal is to increase muscle mass and reduce body fat percentage. I don't travel much, but when I do I like to try the local products of the place where I am.

I come from a large family, there were seven of us, and I was the youngest. Although my mother always prepared generous meals with a starter, two first courses and a second course, until I was ten years old I ate almost exclusively pasta with butter and Parmesan cheese, as well as some raw vegetables such as fennel and artichokes. My family never ate classic pasta with sauce or grilled cutlets; we always ate food that required quite elaborate preparation, such as duck à l'orange. I learnt to cook by spending time in the kitchen with my mother, helping her with age-appropriate tasks and observing how she combined ingredients to create tasty dishes, even when there was seemingly nothing in the fridge. I appreciate all types of cuisine from around the world, and I enjoy experimenting in the kitchen. For example, I loved the ham and jam sandwich I bought in the Netherlands. I prefer fish dishes, especially prawns, but I will eat anything. Raw or cooked vegetables are always a must. Fortunately, I have no food intolerances, so I eat according to my needs at the time without any particular restrictions, always trying to maintain a balance throughout the week. One memorable dinner was at a Japanese restaurant. It wasn't the usual sushi, but sophisticated food that still makes my mouth water when I think about it. In short, I have a very good relationship with food, and I enjoy eating rather than seeing it as merely a means of survival.

I come from Sardinia, from a family that wasn't rich, but never had difficulties. I lived at home with my parents until now. I learned to cook with my father, who taught me to prepare traditional Mediterranean dishes, both for daily meals and special occasions. The cuisine he passed on to me is strongly rooted in Sardinian culinary tradition.

Throughout my life, I've been fortunate to travel in Europe and the United States, where I was able to try different local cuisines and also dishes from other traditions, such as Chinese, Arabic, and South American. These trips helped me discover new ingredients and dishes.

Health-wise, I've had some intestinal problems that influenced my diet for several years. However, today, apart from a mild lactose intolerance, I can eat practically everything without problems.

My current cuisine is quite simple and adapts to the routine of a working student: quick and practical dishes, like pasta with oil and garlic, pesto, ready-made sauces, or even frozen mussels. For the second course, I prefer meat. I don't follow particular restrictions, except for dairy products.

I don't have specific hobbies that influence my food choices, but I can say that the dishes that have most influenced me are those typical of Sardinia, like culurgiones or roast suckling pig. Besides being dishes I find really good, they remind me of moments of celebration and tradition, and this gives me a sense of comfort and belonging.

I have been living in Cagliari for five years for study reasons, sharing a place with other girls, but I grew up in a small village about an hour away. My parents have always led a healthy lifestyle: they have always practiced sports and paid close attention to their diet, and consequently I did the same. I learned how to cook in my first year of university, but I am not very good at it. At home, both of my parents cook. The most memorable lunches and dinners are definitely those at Christmas and Easter, spent together with my whole family.
When I travel, I try to taste local dishes as long as they are not too far from my personal tastes. I like Spanish cuisine, I love paella, and I also enjoy Indian food. Sometimes I try to recreate chicken curry, with not-so-great results. Unfortunately, I cook very simple dishes every day that take no more than 15 minutes. I do not like cooking and I rarely enjoy it; moreover, I am not a foodie. My food-related memories are connected to my family and the time we spend together around the table

I was born in Sardinia and, from an early age, my diet mainly consisted of cured meats, bread, and dairy products. I rarely ate vegetables as a child, although I always consumed fruit. In general, I have never been fond of sweets.

During high school, I occasionally started eating fast food. My first trip to the UK introduced me to some local dishes, such as fish and chips, and it was also my first time trying sushi; however, these experiences did not significantly change my diet. Similarly, a trip to Portugal mainly exposed me to new types of desserts, without influencing my eating habits. A journey to Poland made me realize that I dislike garlic, which was used excessively in the local cuisine.

When I started university and moved away from my family, I made a drastic shift toward a healthier diet, reducing meat consumption and significantly increasing my intake of vegetables. I developed an interest in Japanese animation and, through it, became closer to Asian culinary culture, particularly ramen and sushi. University social life led me to share common group foods such as kebab and sushi. During this period, I began eating more dishes containing onions and spices and stopped using salt. I also made an effort to appreciate local dishes I had disliked as a child, such as asparagus-based meals.

More recently, I have started to approach the world of desserts, as I often go out for breakfast with friends.

I was born in Port Elizabeth and moved to Cape Town 18 years ago where I am now married and have one child. I don't cook very much because of my busy work schedule, but I only learned to cook in my thirties through my partner. 

I have only travelled locally so I have not discovered any unusual cuisines, just the standard Asian & African stuff. My favorite restaurant since I was young has been a franchise called Mike's Kitchen. It is more of a steak ranch.

I have recently been diagnosed with Type 2 diabetes so I have decide to change my diet completely and focus on whole foods, veggies and all things that are beneficial to my health. 

I love going out and attending traditional events which leads to a lot of binging on red meat, animal fat and sugary drinks. Dishes that make an impact on e are the ones that are made by my wife. I am now going to focus on being healthy and exercising to control my blood sugar.

I like food, I traveled the world so I got to know many cuisines. Not only the versions of food from countries exported to mine but the real thing. My preference is Asian food, as it taste the most fresh and emphasizes the taste of the ingredients. From all Asian food my preference is Indonesian, if they make food spicy it not only has thousands levels but they find in every dish a different way to make it spicy, the layers of taste are without number. The food from my own country is very bland so for me it is an adventure every time I go abroad and discover new ways to enjoy food. On top of that it is an integral part of how different people live together, knowing their food and how they eat gives insight in who they are as a people. In some parts of the world it is the most important greeting there is to ask someone  if he has eaten already.

I have a good bad relationship with food, sometimes i eat once a day, sometimes i eat a lot sometimes i don't eat at all, but i am gaining weight irregardless. one issue i had was that i had a sugar craving and i used to eat sweets all day and drink sugary drinks all day, it was so bad that i used to have an issue at night, i would wake up in the middle of the night and drink sugary drink otherwise i would shake uncontrollably and not be able to sleep until i drink something that was filled with sugar. Right now i am tryng to limit my sugar intake as i do not believe that anyone can fully give up sugar and live a healthy life without encountering issues, so right now i prefer small portions and any food that is easy to make but not greasy so that i can keep up.

I am a British born person with roots from Malaysia, I am single, and I currently work as a full-time employee for a large-scale organisation. I have learned to cook from picking up recipes from my mum, who is an excellent cook. I love travelling and often go to countries just for their cuisines, and enjoy cuisines such as Thai, Malaysian, Chinese among others. I mostly eat an 80-20 diet, where the 80 refers to anything healthy for the body, and the 20 refers to 'anything goes'. The reason I do this is to enable long-term good health, and also because I had a recent health scare which prompted me to prioritise my well-being. I would say my favourite cuisine is Malaysian due to my heritage and because of the vast variety of dishes available. I usually cook every day but I have to admit being a lousy cook; my mum often does a lot of the cooking too. I have some restrictions such as gluten, egg white, and yeast intolerance, as well as an egg-white allergy. I like to eat healthily so I can engage in my hobbies and it makes me feel good and alert when engaging in such activities. An important dish that made an impact on me was turnip cakes; this is because it is sentimental and nostalgic, having been one of the earliest dishes I enjoyed.

I am from South Africa and I live with my parents and siblings. I learnt how to cook while I was in University. I grew up being influenced by the cooking of my mother and grandmother. They usually cooked typical German dishes. Lots of meat with thick sauces and side dishes like potatoes or noodles.

I grew up in France and was exposed early on to quality food. I had a wonderful childhood, but sweets and treats were used as bribery and reward.  I feel this has given me a poor relationship with those items.  I seem unable, at times, to control my cravings for items that I would consider treats,  eg  crisps, chocolate, salted nuts.  I was always given good traditional food as a child.  My Mum worked but looking back always managed to cook from scratch.  I disliked meat as far back as I can remember, but was always encouraged to eat it, even though I would complain.  This gave me a severe dislike of meat and as soon as I left home I became a vegetarian. Its something that has lasted a lifetime.  I have signed up for a medical trial on which I take a 14mg tablet of semaglutide.  This does somewhat control my hunger, but doesn't turn off the food noise which makes me indulge in snacks.  My husband does the cooking and has done for 40 odd years.  So I don't have the excuse that I am surrounded by food and forced to cook.  All I know is that at times I feel out of control with my eating.  Not something |I am proud to admit, but honestly it seems to be the case.

I am from Spain and have lived here for most of my live, so my diet is essentially mediterranean. I currently live with my mother and sister, although I've lived on my own for a large part of my life and therefore, I've usually been the one in charge of cooking.

I learned how to cook mainly from my mother, but also through recipes found online and other sources (such as TikTok). Throughout my life, I have traveled to different countries, which has allowed me to discover other cuisines and, for example, to fall in love with Japanese food.

At the moment, I mostly cook for practicality rather than preference, as I do not have much time and cooking has become just another 'daily task'. 

Regarding dietary restrictions, I am lactose intolerant, although it doesn't significantly affect my diet. I try to maintain a balanced diet without obsessing over calories, focusing mainly on the quality of the food and choosing minimally processed products. I also try to exercise regularly, so my diet aims to incluid a good amount of protein.

I am a 63 years old woman living alone. I don't like meat very much. I used to cook a lot when my son was living with me and my late husband. Now I don't want to cook anything anymore. The only thing I want to cook is pureed pumpkin. I buy pre-cooked vegetables, bread, grissini. I have breakfast with some milk, some fruit, and some cereal. Sometimes I make vanilla pudding. I eat a lot of parmesan, and salmon.
I want to control my weight, so I try to avoid sweets.
I hate pasta.
My favorite vegetables are carrots and broccoli.
Sometimes, if I am out with friends, I get some focaccia, or a slice of pizza.
When I have guests, I sometimes cook fish. Besides this, I am not a big fan of meat. I just eat chicken sometimes, when I buy it for my dog, but that is rare.

I grew up in the Philippines and learned to cook from a young age because my grandmother would always string me along to the kitchen so I can watch her cook! My food preferences grew further from watching TLC (the equivalent of the Food Network) in our country, and that channel featured chefs like Gordon Ramsay and Jaime Oliver. I learned to experiment and try different ingredients with food, and it was also around this time that I grew fond of beef. I love to prepare different cuts but my main preference would be a nice Ribeye Steak, which I often have with a couple of eggs and a side of mashed potatoes or even rice, because of my Southeast Asian upbringing. Overall, I would say that my relationship with food these days is highly dependent on macronutrients, I still like good food and food that's not always healthy, but I want to dial in my nutrition as much as I can.

I was born into a good family. I have a sister and my mum and dad were together throughout my childhood. My mum used to teach me how to cook. She was a good cook and often held dinner parties. 
I did seem to gain weight quicker than other members of my family, but I then ate less sweet things, even though they were often my favourites. I found this easier to do when I was younger and with my family. 
When I became an adult living alone I didn't make as good choices and did gain weight. That has led to a yo yo relationship with food throughout my adulthood, gaining weight, trying to lose weight and on and on it goes. I have mostly gotten on top of it now, but it did take a long time for me to realise that I couldn't just lose weight and go back to my old ways and that I needed to keep the new habits and eat more healthy long term.

What an interesting topic! My relationship with food today is very much shaped by my upbringing. My mother was a wonderful cook and both myself and my brother and sister very early on began to equate food with love. My mother struggled financially a lot, but one of the ways that she 'gave' us things was to cook wonderful home-cooked meals for us. She also packed us amazing lunches that were the envy of our classmates. I mention this childhood experience because it very much has translated to me using food as love an adult. One of the ways that I know I show others that I care about them is to bring them food items, such as snacks, treats or meals. I am aware that I do this and know that sometimes it is not a good idea. For example, I have a nephew who is very overweight and I should not shower him with treats the way that I do. But in some ways, I feel that I can't help it. I love making things for people and bringing them food gifts as a way that I show that I care, and I feel my mother's legacy (she passed away in 2008) when I do this. This is the first thing that came to mind when I considered my relationship with food.

Food is something I enjoy and that's needed to get me through the day. I enjoy eating a healthy diet, because it makes me feel good and provides me with energy. I don't do anything special in particular, but feel like I have a good habit of eating a varied diet. On days that I've done a lot of cycling, I tend to eat a bit more or snack more during the activity. Both to provide me with plenty of fuel and to reward myself.
When I'm less active I try to limit the amount of food that I consume and I don't really snack anything. That's the most conscious thing I do in regards to food or diet. 
Besides that I try to eat at least 1 or 2 pieces of fruit every day. In the last 10 years or so I have also changed my habit of eating meat as a standard. I still eat it, but it's not a standard thing to eat everyday anymore. Instead of treating it as a staple, I try to buy something of better quality and more sustainably farmed.

Im from the Netherlands. i live in a small city called Berg en Dal with my girlfriend and 2 young children. I worked as a cook some years ago so i can cook quite a bit. I like steak the most, it must be rare or medium. we often go to Italy i also like there spagatti a lot, and the pizza they make. 3 years ago i started bodybuilding so i made sure i got my proteine from that point. after 1,5 years i stopped doing that because we got pretty bussy with our two young childs. i  did try to get the most of them out of natural food and didn't work with shakes. We cook our selfs almost every day, mostly its me who does the cooking. everyone of our family can eat and will eat almost everything, we all dont like sprouts. Because of sports i tend to eat a bit more than the rest of us. One dish i will remember forever is steak with creamsaus and gamba's, its really good. they served it at a restaurant that is now closed. For now we mostly make easy meals because of the time we have for cooking.

I developed Crohn's disease in my teenage years, I'm now 65, so my relationship with food has been mixed. I've had periods when I was not able to eat food, did not want to eat food and periods when I was very fussy about the foods I would eat. However for the past number of years my relationship with food has been quite good, I feel. I eat three meals a day and maintain a healthy balance of foods that tend to be be fairly plain and quite traditional. I also cook the vast majority of my meaLs from scratch and don't eat out very often at all. 

My preference is very much in the vein of a main meal that tends to be meat and two veg, a breakfast that is cereal and toast, and lunch that is a sandwich and a piece of cake. I don't drink alcohol and my weight is very stable.

I am Bulgarian, but I live in Greece. In general, food is a big part of my life. I started cooking when I was 13. I visit fish and food markets every week at least once to buy local food, as I prefer local producers. It is very important for me and my family to eat fresh and delicious food. We have breakfast together almost everyday, and almost everyday we prepare the dinner together which consist some protein(meat or fish), and salads. 
When we go out to a restaurant, we always choose carefully so we can be sure we will get the best food and customer service. 
My parents were spending alot of time in the kitchen and all my memories with them include food - either preparing or eating. Every summer we were spending almost every weekend making food for the winter like: pickles, tomatoes and many others. So the love for food comes from them

I'm from Spain and I've born there. I am vegan since 10 years ago, so I don't eat meat, fish, eggs, etc. My main reasons for being a vegan are ethical reasons with the animals, not the ecological factor, which I'm also a little bit worry. I'm also autist so some food textures annoy me, I'm kind of a picky eater. Also like 8 years ago I tried the jimmyjoy sustitutive shakes, which  I became a fan since, they are like a protein shake but full of nutrients and vitamins, so when I don't want to eat something solid, I just prepare a shake in a minute or so and I have a full diet. I don't have any known food allergies but the red berries make my stomach hurt a bit. I don't practice any sports so I have a very sedentary lifestyle. When I travel, I tend to be very conservative about the food I order

I adore food, there isn't much that I don't like apart from spearmint and rice pudding! When I was a young child my favourite foods were prawns and blue cheese, which is somewhat unusual for a 3 year old.  One of my first memories is of being pushed around Leeds indoor market eating a bag of shell on prawns.  I learned to cook partly from my Grandmother and partly self taught.  My main fault is giving people too big portions, I often get told off for this!  A few years ago I was told that my cholestorol was a bit high, and that the only reason they could think of was that I ate a lot of cheese, including whole camemberts.  I have sorted that out now, and hope that it will remain normal.  Other than that I am lucky enough not to have any specific dietry requirements.  I prefer savoury foods to sweet, and I'm not able to eat lots of chocolates without feeling a bit nauseous.

I'm from Spain, and I'm a member of a monoparental family. I've lived in the same place for most of my life, except for one year that I lived abroad in Mexico, where I got to discover a lot about a different culture and gastronomy. I tend to travel as much as my time and savings allow me, considering myself a very rich person in terms of cultural and international experiences. 
As my habits, I work every week day, and I usually go to crossfit or for a run 3 times per week. I try to eat as healthy as possible when I'm at home, but when I meet with my girlfriend or friends, I don't overthink about what I'm eating or drinking. 
I have a couple of different hobbies. My main hobby is watching esports, but since they usually have fixed schedules, it only happens a couple of times a week. Apart from that, I really enjoy listening to piano music and reading about astronomy.
One of the things that I enjoy the most too is going to the movies. I always prefer to watch a movie that I have interest in in the movies rather than at home.

I have a strong relationship with food and I enjoy it a lot.  My mom didn't really like to cook when I was growing up and our diet was very bland and mostly processed prepared food without a lot of variety.  When I went away to college, I actually encountered more different kinds of food in my school cafeteria and from friends at school.  Once I moved out on my own, I learned to cook so that I could continue to eat the variety of foods that I had learned about.  As I started making more money, I also started trying more ethnic restaurants and learning about different cuisines.  Eventually, I met my husband, who is Chinese, which opened up a lot of different cooking styles and flavors.  I got more confident with my cooking skills and now I love to try out new recipes and restaurants and learn about all of the different types of food that are out there.  I've learned that I get bored eating the same things over and over again like my parents and I aim for a high level of variety in my diet with different flavors each day or week.  I do not like eating the same meals on rotation and enjoy shopping at ethnic markets and similar types of stores.

I grew up with a mother who loved to cook and experiment with different food ideas. She let me in the kitchen at a young age to help, first with small things, and then more advanced. Eating was a pleasure in our house. 
After I got married I bought a lot of cookbooks from different cuisines and liked experimenting and trying new foods. 
Lately, now that I'm older, I have tired of cooking for me and my husband, and seek out easy and quick recipes that are tasty but generally healthy. We don't eat a lot any more, so small is good.
My children, both boys, love to cook, and I have to credit myself for that. They are both creative and efficient in the kitchen.
I have no food allergies, so anything goes. I love all kinds of cuisine, but Mexican is my favorite. 
Occasionally I buy frozen meals when I'm sick of making a dinner menu.

I came from Belgium my relationship with food was alwasy unhealthy my mom was always filling my backpack to school withh sweets and chocolates, and there were always chocolate, sweets at home so I developed quit an addiction to sugar during my childhood, I learned to cook at 22 but not much just simples meals like scrambled eggs, cooking meats and simples things like that my memorable meal is scrambled egg since it was the first one I manaed to cook I was so pride of it, I discovered greek food and I discovered how well they cook seafood and there gyros is very good, at 20 I was obese 113kg and I couldn't stand it up anymore so I decided to start a diet and limiting my daily calories I also started 2 years after working out and walking 10k steps per day and it changed my life and relationship to food I feel much more healthy now, I currently eat eggs with bread cottage cheese, honey, and advocado in the evening I often eat simple meals with meats and rice or some alternative to rice, I also often eat fruits betweens meals to not feel hungry, I limit how much calories I eat per day 500-700 calories under my maintenance calorie

I am almost 70 years old. I figure I got 5 good years left. I eat whatever I want. I do not care if it is unhealthy. I eat what tastes good. I do not want anyone to tell me that what I do is unhealthy. I am going to enjoy what remaining years I have. If my life is shortened by months because of what I eat, then so be it. I am going to live life and not be in chains because it elongates my life by another year. Its not worth it. I believe I am going to heaven, which is a far better deal than I got down here. My wife is a health advocate. No salt on anything. So I have my own personalized salt shaker. It's silly to have French fries without salt. Why bother. I love popcorn, steaks, hamburgers, fish, Chinese food, and potato chips, Fritos, spaghetti with thick spaghetti sauce, all of which have salt in one form or another. One other thing, with the hamburgers, the juicier and greasier, in fact, so greasy that the juices soak into the bottom of the paper bag, that the bottom breaks open type of grease, the better.
